data.title: The Ministry of Ungentlemanly Warfare review — a misfire from Guy Ritchie
data.meta_description: The director’s Prime Video movie is a flat, uninspired take on Operation Postmaster
data.text:
What’s going on with Guy Ritchie? Is he struggling with especially high mortgage repayments? There must be some explanation for his relatively recent reinvention as a slapdash purveyor of quickie B-list dross. This is a film-maker, remember, who used to release highly authored, must-see projects (Snatch, Sherlock Holmes, The Man from U.N.C.L.E) every two to four years. But since 2019 he’s bashed out six movies of increasingly poor quality and bland, impersonal direction.

This latest misfire, The Ministry of Ungentlemanly Warfare, cuts the deepest because it so clearly lies within Ritchie’s creative purview. Like Lock, Stock meets Where Eagles Dare, it’s the true story of Operation Postmaster, a top secret Second World War mission involving an eccentric band of British special
